docs.abstract: Political news from today's Times and around the Web, plus a look at the latest happenings in Washington.
docs.snippet: Political news from today's Times and around the Web, plus a look at the latest happenings in Washington.

headline.main: What Must Be Done Now to Save the Euro?

docs.abstract: Europe’s leaders and the European Central Bank must act aggressively and quickly to stabilize a perilous economic situation.
docs.snippet: Europe’s leaders and the European Central Bank must act aggressively and quickly to stabilize a perilous economic situation.

docs.lead_paragraph: After claiming that the health care law is terrible for the country, Mitt Romney didn’t give much of an explanation of what he’d do differently other than repeal it.

headline.seo: The Medical Care Ruling: The Right Responds
headline.main: A Muddled Political Response From the Right
headline.print_headline: The Court and Medical Care: A muddled political response from the right

docs.abstract: Editorial contends that in the wake of the Supreme Court decision upholding the health care reform law, the fate of health care is in the hands of the voting public; criticizes Mitt Romney's response to the ruling as incoherent and calls on Romney to explain his plans for addressing health care should he become president, other than pushing for a repeal of the law.
docs.snippet: After claiming that the health care law is terrible for the country, Mitt Romney didn’t give much of an explanation of what he’d do differently other than repeal it.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: While the importance of the decision can’t be understated, it could make it harder for Congress to pass laws based on the Constitution’s commerce clause.

headline.seo: The Medical Care Ruling: Risks Ahead
headline.main: A Moderate Ruling With Risks Ahead
headline.print_headline: The Court and Medical Care: A moderate ruling with risks ahead

docs.abstract: Editorial underscores the importance of the Supreme Court's decision upholding the health care reform law; applauds the decision, but warns that its constitutional implications are worrying.
docs.snippet: While the importance of the decision can’t be understated, it could make it harder for Congress to pass laws based on the Constitution’s commerce clause.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruling upholding Obamacare certainly is a big victory for the president, all right, but the real winners are people like you.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column contends that the American people are the big winners from the Supreme Court's decision to uphold the health care reform law; criticizes the unscrupulous nature of those opposed to law and warns that the debate over health care is far from over.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court ruling upholding Obamacare certainly is a big victory for the president, all right, but the real winners are people like you.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: By opening up new avenues for the courts to rewrite the law, the federal government may have won the battle but lost the war.

headline.seo: In Health Care Ruling, a Pyrrhic Victory

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by law professor Neal K Katyal warns that the Supreme Court's decision on the health care reform law contains the seeds for a potential restructuring of federal-state relations; asserts that the decision also reinforces the fact that Americans are growing increasingly comfortable with the idea of the court handing down rulings that remove decisions from the legislative process or even rewrite legislation altogether.
docs.snippet: By opening up new avenues for the courts to rewrite the law, the federal government may have won the battle but lost the war.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A number of largely Republican-led states that gambled on a delay of the health care overhaul might now have to scramble to implement its changes.

headline.main: States Face a Challenge to Meet Health Law’s Deadline
headline.print_headline: The Pressure Mounts To Hit Law’s Deadlines

docs.abstract: Supreme Court’s decision to uphold the Affordable Care Act means that a number Republican-led states that gambled on delay must scramble to implement its changes; a particular challenge will be setting up the health insurance marketplaces, or exchanges, where people will be able to choose among policies for their coverage.
docs.snippet: A number of largely Republican-led states that gambled on a delay of the health care overhaul might now have to scramble to implement its changes.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

byline.original: By KEVIN SACK and REED ABELSON

docs.lead_paragraph: By considering the penalty for not buying health insurance a tax, the Supreme Court created a tax that people will pay only if they do not buy something.

headline.seo: Supreme Court Calls Insurance Penalty a Tax
headline.main: Justices Allow the Term ‘Tax’ to Embrace ‘Penalty’
headline.print_headline: Justices Allow the Term ‘Tax’ to Embrace ‘Penalty’

docs.abstract: Supreme Court, by considering the penalty for not buying health insurance a tax, effectively creates a tax that people will pay only if they do not buy something; decision leads some opponents of the health care law to proclaim that it is a large tax increase, something the sponsors of the bill had explicitly denied when the law was passed; to some extent, calling it a tax breaks new ground.
docs.snippet: By considering the penalty for not buying health insurance a tax, the Supreme Court created a tax that people will pay only if they do not buy something.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The self-restraint of Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. has allowed for a process of discovery and innovation to enter the health care debate.
docs.abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column applauds Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts Jr's majority opinion on the health care law for its restraint; contends that by limiting the power of the court to shape health care policy, Roberts allows the voters to determine the future of health care; predicts that the ruling will accelerate the health care debate.
docs.snippet: The self-restraint of Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. has allowed for a process of discovery and innovation to enter the health care debate.
